results.title: Birth of Indigenous broadcasting
results.brief_description: From the 1970s, Aboriginal Elders in Central Australia were concerned that satellite TV could potentially bring non-Indigenous stories to remote Aboriginal communities. In response, several Aboriginal media organisations broadcast local content via videotape and pirate TV, leading to the eventual establishment of Indigenous broadcasters.

constellations_primary.name: Broadcasting marginal voices
constellations_primary.description: The creation of Indigenous broadcasting in Central Australia from the late 1970s meant an array of diverse Black stories could be shared. Today, important stories told by those who physically and metaphorically live on the margins can be broadcast widely.

results.description: From the 1970s, Aboriginal Elders in Central Australia were concerned satellite TV potentially bringing non-Indigenous stories and storytelling to remote Aboriginal communities. In response, several Aboriginal media organisations, like Ernabella Video Television (EVTV) and the Warlpiri Media Association (WMA), broadcast local content via videotape and pirate TV in the early 1980s. Filmed in Aboriginal languages, these videos included community events, ceremonies, lore and culture. In 1998, the Central Australian Aboriginal Media Association (CAAMA) launched the world’s first Indigenous owned and operated TV network, Imparja Television. Along with the establishment of Indigenous Community Television (ICTV) in 2001, these early initiatives paved the way for other broadcasters, including Goolarri Media Enterprises and National Indigenous Television (NITV).
description_for_label: From the 1970s, Aboriginal Elders in Central Australia were concerned satellite TV potentially bringing non-Indigenous stories and storytelling to remote Aboriginal communities. In response, several Aboriginal media organisations, like Ernabella Video Television (EVTV) and the Warlpiri Media Association (WMA), broadcast local content via videotape and pirate TV in the early 1980s. Filmed in Aboriginal languages, these videos included community events, ceremonies, lore and culture. In 1998, the Central Australian Aboriginal Media Association (CAAMA) launched the world’s first Indigenous owned and operated TV network, Imparja Television. Along with the establishment of Indigenous Community Television (ICTV) in 2001, these early initiatives paved the way for other broadcasters, including Goolarri Media Enterprises and National Indigenous Television (NITV).

results.title: My Survival as an Aboriginal
results.credit_line: Courtesy the Coffey family and Martha Ansara / the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia / Ballad Films
results.brief_description: Essie Coffey OAM was a Murawarri activist, advocate and filmmaker concerned about the influence of white culture and education on Indigenous children. As seen in her groundbreaking documentary, My Survival as an Aboriginal (1978), she taught culture to her community.

constellations_primary.name: Black documentary and truth telling
constellations_primary.description: Essie Coffey was a trailblazer of Indigenous filmmaking, being the first Aboriginal woman to direct a documentary. The film spotlights the outspoken voice Coffey utilised to convey the realities faced by Aboriginal people and to encourage resistance to assimilation.

constellations_other.name: Women in charge
constellations_other.description: Across documentary, film, TV, and visual art, Aboriginal women have led how they will be represented on-screen.

constellations_other.name: Jedda: Uneven ground, the road to on-screen diversity
constellations_other.description: Jedda was the first fully funded Australian feature to be shot on colour film. It was also the first Australian film with Aboriginal actors in lead roles, however, it reflects a deeply problematic time in Australian history.

constellations_other.name: Connecting through film
constellations_other.description: Film acts like a time capsule to our collective past. Capturing our most treasured moments with family has never been more accessible, with technology right at our fingers.

results.description: Essie Coffey OAM was a Murawarri activist, advocate and filmmaker concerned about the influence of white culture and education on Indigenous children. As seen in her groundbreaking documentary, My Survival as an Aboriginal (1978), she taught culture – and the importance of cultural knowledge – to her community. Importantly, her documentary also exposed how First Peoples were marginalised in all aspects of their lives, from school to wider society. The treatment of First Peoples laid bare in her documentary reached wider audiences through screenings at prestigious Australian and international film festivals, where the film won numerous awards. For her dedicated services to the Indigenous Australian community, Coffey herself was awarded an Order of Australia.
description_for_label: Essie Coffey OAM was a Murawarri activist, advocate and filmmaker concerned about the influence of white culture and education on Indigenous children. As seen in her groundbreaking documentary, My Survival as an Aboriginal (1978), she taught culture – and the importance of cultural knowledge – to her community. Importantly, her documentary also exposed how First Peoples were marginalised in all aspects of their lives, from school to wider society. The treatment of First Peoples laid bare in her documentary reached wider audiences through screenings at prestigious Australian and international film festivals, where the film won numerous awards. For her dedicated services to the Indigenous Australian community, Coffey herself was awarded an Order of Australia.
results.credit_line_for_label: Courtesy the Coffey family and Martha Ansara / the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia / Ballad Films
